name: bargaining
content:
bargaining

noun
 
/ˈbɑːɡənɪŋ/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. discussion of prices, conditions, etc. with the aim of reaching an agreement that is acceptable synonym negotiation
    • After much hard bargaining we reached an agreement.
    • wage bargaining
    • Exporters are in a strong bargaining position at the moment.
    see also collective bargaining, plea bargainingTopics Discussion and agreementc1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • hard
    • collective
    • institutional
    • …
    bargaining + noun
    • position
    • power
    • chip
    • …
    See full entry
See bargaining in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee bargaining in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: bargaining

name: bargain
content:
bargain

verb
 
/ˈbɑːɡən/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡən/
 [intransitive]
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they bargain
 
/ˈbɑːɡən/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡən/
he / she / it bargains
 
/ˈbɑːɡənz/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənz/
past simple bargained
 
/ˈbɑːɡənd/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənd/
past participle bargained
 
/ˈbɑːɡənd/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənd/
-ing form bargaining
 
/ˈbɑːɡənɪŋ/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1. ​to discuss prices, conditions, etc. with somebody in order to reach an agreement that is acceptable synonym negotiate
    • bargain (with somebody) (about/over/for something) In the market dealers were bargaining with growers over the price of coffee.
    • He said he wasn't prepared to bargain.
    Extra Examples
    • He bargained hard and was stubborn.
    • He tried to bargain with her.
    • He was prepared to bargain about money.
    • Crowds of men were bargaining over horses.
    • They just want to bargain for a decent wage.
    • They argued forecfully for the right of workers to bargain collectively.
    Topics Discussion and agreementc1, Shoppingc1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • hard
    • collectively
    preposition
    • about
    • for
    • over
    • …
    See full entry
    Word OriginMiddle English: from Old French bargaine (noun), bargaignier (verb); probably of Germanic origin and related to German borgen ‘borrow’.
Phrasal Verbs
  • bargain away
  • bargain for
  • bargain on
See bargain in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee bargain in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: bargain

name: bargaining chip
content:
bargaining chip

noun
 
/ˈbɑːɡənɪŋ tʃɪp/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənɪŋ tʃɪp/
(British English also bargaining counter)
jump to other results
  1. ​a fact or a thing that a person or a group of people can use to get an advantage for themselves when they are trying to reach an agreement with another group
    • The release of the prisoners was used as a bargaining chip.
    • Ownership of the land gives us a strong bargaining counter.
    • Should nuclear weapons be used as bargaining chips in arms negotiations?
    Topics Discussion and agreementc2
See bargaining chip in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bargaining chip

name: bargaining power
content:
bargaining power

noun
 
/ˈbɑːɡənɪŋ paʊə(r)/
 
/ˈbɑːrɡənɪŋ paʊər/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. ​the amount of control a person or group has when trying to reach an agreement with another group in a business or political situation
    • The smaller states’ efforts to exercise their collective bargaining power against multinationals have failed.
    Topics Discussion and agreementc1, Businessc1
See bargaining power in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee bargaining power in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: bargaining power

name: plea bargaining
content:
plea bargaining

noun
 
/ˈpliː bɑːɡənɪŋ/
 
/ˈpliː bɑːrɡənɪŋ/
[uncountable] (law)
jump to other results
  1. ​the process of making an arrangement in court by which a person admits to being guilty of a smaller crime in the hope of receiving less severe punishment for a more serious crime
    • They received suspended prison sentences after plea bargaining by their lawyers.
    compare cop a plea
See plea bargaining in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: plea bargaining

name: collective bargaining
content:
collective bargaining

noun
 
/kəˌlektɪv ˈbɑːɡənɪŋ/
 
/kəˌlektɪv ˈbɑːrɡənɪŋ/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. ​discussions between a trade union and an employer about the pay and working conditions of the union members
    • Unions were insistent on the right to collective bargaining.
    Wordfinder
    • ballot
    • closed shop
    • collective bargaining
    • industrial action
    • labour
    • picket
    • protest
    • representative
    • strike
    • union
See collective bargaining in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee collective bargaining in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: enterprise bargaining
content:
enterprise bargaining

noun
 
/ˌentəpraɪz ˈbɑːɡənɪŋ/
 
/ˌentərpraɪz ˈbɑːrɡənɪŋ/
[uncountable] (Australian English)
jump to other results
  1. ​discussions between employers and employees about pay and working conditions
    • In the latest round of enterprise bargaining, employees have been offered pay rises of between 0.5 and 1.2 per cent.
Check pronunciation: enterprise bargaining
